The material in this course was new to me.  However, the professor did an exceptional job presenting the information in a manner in which it was accessible.   The course is a step by step introduction of solid-state physics, walking the student through crystal structures, phonon and electron modes, and finally semiconductors and devices.
I understand the lattice structure, phonons and electrons behavior, and the band structure, semiconductors, dielectrics.

I felt I learned the basic physics that govern crystalline materials in the solid phase. Additionally, I gained a good conceptual understanding of solid state physics.

Everything is good. Professor Victor Henrich is a very good teacher. Because I only take the first solid state course, if possible, I hope professor Victor Henrich could talk something about superconductor and superconductivity, because this is a very important topic in solid-state physics.

The strength is the material in addition to the professor's clear passion for it. Given the focus is conceptual understanding, more thorough reading materials on the latter third of the class would have been invaluable.
In my opinion I think this course is great and I find no weakness about it.

The instructor for this course put a great deal of effort into developing each lesson plan.  Unlike many courses I have taken at Yale, where the instruction seems like an afterthought, it is clear that the professor is dedicated to ensuring the students  get the most out of each lecture.

Strength: every point is clear and Victor is really patient to answer my questions.

Weakness: Too fast, sometimes cannot catch up with the point.
This course covers lot of things, from solid state physics, semiconductor physics, to semiconductor devices, light-matter interaction, etc. I love this course.
The detailed reduction of some important formulas should be done in the class. Meanwhile, the exam should contain important derivations.

Let me start by saying I recognize that a first course in solid state physics is hard to teach. The interests of theorists and experimentalists vary greatly in this subject. With that said, I feel the course taught fall of 2017 was too focused on concepts of interest for experimentalists. Lecture derivations were surface level and felt rushed. When students would ask for more depth there didn't appear to be much interest from the instructor to give deeper explanations. Maybe this was forward thinking about what was necessary to understand future topics and concern over the length of the course. All I know is I was left feeling a bit empty about what was covered. I recommend teaching a more well rounded course to better satisfy both theoretical and experimental interests. Again, I realize this is easier said then done.
I think it is good enough for a first-year course. All the materials are arranged in a logic way and I could review some concepts and explore more new parts in solid state physics in this class.

One major strength of this course was providing a conceptual understanding of the physics that drive processes in crystalline materials. Over this course, there was a constant stress on relating different topics thinking deeply about how to use the basic knowledge we learned to answer difficult questions.
For students in physics, applied physics, and electrical engineering, I will highly recommend this course to them.
The course material is interesting and excellent. The professor is engaging and caring. You will need to understand the material -- not simply know how to use equations.

I would recommend this course to another student. Because this course can serve as a roadmap to this field. It can give a clear picture of the field. I felt my understandings of this field have been deepened since I took this course.

If someone has taken a course in solid state physics previously I would not recommend this course. If someone hasn't then yes I would recommend it.
